4.text: On behalf of the Board of Directors, we want to thank you for your investment in Visa and encourage you to vote

5.text: your shares by proxy at this year’s Annual Meeting. There are five matters on the agenda: the election of

6.text: directors, Say-on-Pay, advisory vote on the frequency of future advisory votes on executive compensation,

7.text: ratification of the auditors, and one stockholder proposal.

8.text: At Visa, we are guided by our purpose, which is to uplift everyone, everywhere by being the best way to pay and

9.text: be paid. Our purpose is demonstrated in our business and in our environmental, social, and governance (ESG)

10.text: efforts, which are an important priority for Visa and continue to be an increasing focus for our investors, partners,

11.text: and employees, as well as governments and other stakeholders.

12.text: Our Board oversees our ESG strategy and activities at both the full Board and committee levels, with the

13.text: Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee having formal responsibility for oversight of our ESG policies

14.text: and programs. Throughout the year, we made significant progress across each of our five ESG pillars:

15.text: Empowering People & Economies, Securing Commerce & Protecting Customers, Investing in Our Workforce,

16.text: Protecting the Planet, and Operating Responsibly. Some highlights across these pillars include:

17.text: • We have helped digitally enable over 40 million small and micro businesses as of September 2022, as

18.text: we work toward our goal of reaching 50 million by the end of 2023.

19.text: • We have invested over $10 billion in technology over the last five years, including to reduce fraud and

21.text: • We achieved the highest rating in our sector from Gartner Consulting during our 2022 cybersecurity

23.text: • We supported more than 6,000 employees from 58 countries who volunteered more than 55,000 hours to

24.text: strengthen the communities in which we live and work.

25.text: • We completed the first year of the Visa Black Scholars and Jobs Program, hosted the inaugural Visa

26.text: Black Scholars Summit, and welcomed our second cohort of scholars to continue building on the

28.text: • We received third party validation of our 2030 science-based target as an interim goal toward our 2040

29.text: net zero target. This builds on Visa’s achievement of purchasing 100% renewable electricity and attaining

30.text: carbon neutrality for our operations in 2020.

31.text: • We advanced on our aspiration to be a climate positive company through expanded sustainability

32.text: solutions, such as the Visa Eco Benefits bundle, for our clients.

33.text: • We continued to receive recognition of our ESG leadership from third-party organizations, including

34.text: inclusion in the Bloomberg Gender Equality Index, the Dow Jones Sustainability North America Index for

35.text: the fifth consecutive year, and Ethisphere’s World’s Most Ethical Companies for the tenth consecutive year.

36.text: This year, Visa’s corporate governance practices continued to help promote long-term value and strong Board

37.text: and management accountability to our diverse set of stakeholders. The Board is focused on prioritizing the right

38.text: mix of skills, qualifications, experiences, tenure, and diversity to promote and support Visa’s long-term strategy.

39.text: Women comprise 30% of the Board’s nominees, and 40% of the Board’s nominees are racially or ethnically

40.text: diverse. During 2022 we welcomed two independent directors to the Board, Teri L. List and Kermit R. Crawford.

41.text: Teri and Kermit each bring decades of senior leadership experience to the Board, providing diverse perspectives

42.text: and expertise that will be invaluable to Visa. In addition, Mary Cranston and Bob Matschullat will be retiring from

43.text: the Board at this year’s Annual Meeting after contributing 15 years of distinguished leadership and service,

44.text: including as committee chairs, and with Bob serving as our former Chairman of the Board. On behalf of the

45.text: Board, we sincerely thank Mary and Bob for their dedicated service and many contributions to Visa over the

47.text: Finally, as we have recently announced, we are pleased to share that Ryan McInerney will be Visa’s next Chief

48.text: Executive Officer, and Al Kelly will move to the role of Executive Chairman, both effective February 1, 2023. The

49.text: Board of Directors also expects to appoint Ryan to the Board effective upon his transition to Chief Executive

50.text: Officer. This leadership change reflects the Board’s thoughtful and well-established approach to succession. Ryan

51.text: is a very seasoned leader in the payments and consumer banking industry. In his role as President over the past

52.text: 10 years, Ryan has been responsible for Visa’s global businesses, delivering value to the company’s financial

53.text: institutions, acquirers, merchants, and partners in more than 200 countries and territories around the world. He

54.text: has overseen the company’s market teams, business units, product team, merchant team, and client services.

55.text: We look forward to working with Ryan to continue to drive Visa’s success, growth, and innovation.

56.text: Thank you for your continued support of Visa, and we look forward to your attendance at this year’s Annual Meeting.

313.title: Our Compensation Philosophy, Principles, and Key Elements

314.text: The compensation program for our named executive officers (NEOs) helps us attract and retain key talent and

315.text: promote performance that enhances stockholder value and drives long-term strategic outcomes, including the

317.text: There are three primary principles that guide our compensation program design and administration: (1) pay for

318.text: performance; (2) promote alignment with stakeholders’ interests; and (3) attract, motivate, and retain key talent.

319.text: We tie a substantial portion of our NEOs’ target annual compensation to the achievement of pre-established

320.text: financial and non-financial objectives that support our business strategy, with a mix that balances short- and long

321.text: term performance goals. Further, our annual incentive plan incorporates ESG metrics that are tied to the

322.text: Company’s strategic objectives. Our long-term equity awards align the interests of our NEOs with our

323.text: stakeholders’ interests and link a substantial portion of compensation to the achievement of earnings per share

324.text: (EPS) results that drive stockholder value and relative total shareholder return (TSR).

325.text: For fiscal year 2022, 94% of the target total direct compensation for our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

326.text: was variable and at risk, and an average of 92% was variable and at risk for our other NEOs.

456.title: BOARD’S ROLE IN LONG-TERM STRATEGIC PLANNING

457.text: The Board takes an active role with management to formulate and review Visa’s long-term corporate strategy.

458.text: Each quarter, the Board and management confer on the execution of our long-term strategic plans, and the status

459.text: of key initiatives, opportunities, and risks facing Visa. In addition, the Board regularly conducts in-depth long-term

460.text: strategic reviews with our senior management team. During these reviews, the Board and management discuss

461.text: the payments landscape, emerging technological and competitive threats, and short- and long-term plans and

463.text: Additionally, the Board annually discusses and approves the budget and capital requests, which are firmly linked

464.text: to Visa’s long-term strategic plans and priorities. Through these processes, the Board brings its collective,

465.text: independent judgment to bear on the most critical long-term strategic issues facing Visa. For more information on

466.text: our long-term strategy and the progress we made against our strategic goals in fiscal year 2022, please see our

467.text: 2022 Annual Report, including the letter from our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Alfred F. Kelly, Jr., to our

480.text: Attracting, developing, and advancing the best people globally is crucial to all aspects of Visa’s activities and long

481.text: term success, and is central to our long-term strategy. Best-in-class, diverse teams and an inclusive culture

482.text: inspire leadership, encourage innovative thinking, and support the development and advancement of all

484.text: These guiding principles have been more important than ever in light of the continuing challenges posed by

485.text: events such as the COVID-19 pandemic and the impact of developments related to the war in Ukraine. At Visa,

486.text: we are committed to the health and safety of our employees and their families. In fiscal year 2022, a large

487.text: majority of our workforce continued to work remotely for the first half of the year, and we maintained strong safety

488.text: protocols and procedures consistent with applicable requirements and guidelines for the employees who

489.text: continued to work on site. To meet the evolving needs of our workforce, we deepened our commitment to

490.text: employee wellbeing, through broad engagement with our leadership, targeted programs, and expanded benefits.

491.text: We also executed a phased approach to reopening our offices, with employee health and wellbeing as a top

492.text: priority. We are providing our employees with enhanced flexibility in how and where we work while maintaining

493.text: collaboration and community. As we plan for the future of work, we expect to monitor and evolve our approach to

494.text: continue to provide the right flexible balance for Visa.

495.text: At Visa, all employees are encouraged and empowered to be leaders through embracing the Visa Leadership

496.text: Principles. These Leadership Principles are integrated into core talent processes, and employees are evaluated

497.text: not only on their performance, but also how they embody the Leadership Principles:

543.text: The tone and culture of Visa is set at the Board level. The full Board has oversight of human capital management

544.text: and performs regular reviews, including annual reviews of succession planning for our Chief Executive Officer.

545.text: Our Board committees have responsibility for specific areas of human capital management. The Nominating and

546.text: Corporate Governance Committee is responsible for director succession and refreshment, as well as

547.text: management succession and development planning. Our Compensation Committee is responsible for reviewing

548.text: Visa’s programs and practices related to executive workforce inclusion and diversity as well as the administration

549.text: of compensation programs in a non-discriminatory manner. Management is responsible for developing policies

550.text: and processes that reflect and reinforce our desired corporate culture, including policies and processes related to

551.text: strategy, risk management, and ethics and compliance.

553.text: Visa understands that being an employer of choice requires best-in-class career and skills development along

554.text: with innovative programs. This year, we introduced a career framework with philosophies and tools for employees

555.text: to plan their growth and career at Visa. We also implemented new guidelines to drive increased internal mobility

556.text: for employees. We support employees in their development through our award-winning Visa University. Our

557.text: global learning platform, Learning Hub, houses more than 200,000 learning resources on a number of topics,

558.text: including sales, technology, product, and leadership development training on our gamified platform. Visa’s annual

559.text: Learning Festival includes courses taught and facilitated by Visa leaders and external speakers who bring real

560.text: world context and ideas for practical application that are aligned with our goals.

562.text: We recognize that building an inclusive and high-performing culture requires an engaged workforce, where

563.text: employees are motivated to do their best work every day. Our engagement approach centers on communication

564.text: and recognition. We communicate with our employees in a variety of ways, including biweekly video updates from

565.text: our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, company intranet, digital signage, email newsletters, live events in

566.text: regional offices, and quarterly all-staff meetings. Our recognition programs include our Go Beyond platform,

567.text: where managers and peers recognize employees who exemplify our leadership principles. In 2022, we created

568.text: our new Employee Value Proposition, Powering Payments, Empowering People, which is closely linked to our

569.text: purpose and will be used to attract, develop, and advance top-notch talent.

570.text: We assess employee engagement through a variety of channels, including employee pulse surveys, which

571.text: provide feedback on a variety of topics, such as company direction and strategy, wellbeing, inclusion and

572.text: diversity, individual growth and development, collaboration, and confidence and pride.

574.text: We believe our employees are critical to the success of our business, and we structure our total rewards and

575.text: benefits package to attract and retain a talented and engaged workforce. We continue to evolve our programs to

576.text: meet our employees’ needs, providing comprehensive wellbeing, financial, and quality of life coverage. Our

577.text: programs vary by location, but may include the following:

616.text: business success. By leveraging the diverse backgrounds and perspectives of our worldwide teams, we are able

617.text: to achieve better solutions for our clients and create a connected workplace to attract and advance top talent.

706.text: Al Kelly currently serves as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and John Lundgren serves as Lead

707.text: Independent Director. While the Company does not have a policy on whether the roles of Chairperson and Chief

708.text: Executive Officer should be split, the Board believes that the combined role is in the best interests of the

709.text: Company and its stockholders at this time, as this structure allows Mr. Kelly to effectively manage the business,

710.text: execute on our strategic priorities, and lead the Board, while empowering Mr. Lundgren to provide independent

711.text: Board leadership and oversight. The Board believes that Mr. Kelly’s inclusive leadership style and decades of

712.text: payments expertise make him uniquely qualified to lead discussions of the Board; foster an important unity of

713.text: leadership between the Board and management; and promote alignment of the Company’s strategy with its

714.text: operational execution. Upon effecting the Chief Executive Officer transition on February 1, 2023, the Board has

715.text: determined that Mr. Kelly will continue to serve as Executive Chairman. Mr. Lundgren has significant experience

716.text: as a CEO, including in a combined role of CEO and Chair, so he is familiar with the combined board leadership

717.text: structure and the importance of building strong relationships with the various constituencies.

746.title: Board of Directors and Committee Evaluations

747.text: Our Board recognizes that a robust and constructive Board and committee evaluation process is an essential

748.text: component of Board effectiveness. As such, our Board and each of its committees conduct an annual evaluation

749.text: facilitated by an independent third party, which includes a qualitative assessment by each director of the

750.text: performance of the Board and the committee or committees on which the director sits. The Board also conducts

751.text: an annual peer review, which is designed to assess individual director performance. The Nominating and

752.text: Corporate Governance Committee, in conjunction with the Lead Independent Director, oversees the evaluation

786.text: Over the past few years, the evaluation process has led to a broader scope of topics covered in the Board meetings,

787.text: improvements in Board process, and changes to Board and committee composition and structure.

788.text: This year’s evaluation identified areas for continued focus, including:

793.title: Director Succession Planning and Board Refreshment

794.text: In addition to executive and management succession, the Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee

795.text: regularly oversees and plans for director succession and refreshment of the Board to cultivate a mix of skills,

796.text: experience, tenure, and diversity that promote and support the Company’s long-term strategy. In doing so, the

798.text: Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee takes into consideration the overall needs, composition, and

799.text: size of the Board, as well as the criteria adopted by the Board regarding director candidate qualifications, which

800.text: are described in the section entitled Committees of the Board of Directors – Criteria for Nomination to the Board

802.text: qualified to become directors are then recommended to the Board for nomination or election.

804.text: The NYSE’s listing standards and our Corporate Governance Guidelines provide that a majority of our Board and

805.text: every member of the Audit and Risk, Compensation, and Nominating and Corporate Governance committees

806.text: must be “independent.” Our Certificate of Incorporation further requires that at least 58% of our Board be

807.text: independent. Under the NYSE’s listing standards, our Corporate Governance Guidelines, and our Certificate of

1088.text: Visa has a Political Participation, Lobbying and Contributions Policy (PPLC Policy) that prohibits our directors,

1322.title: Certain Relationships and Related Person Transactions

1323.text: The Audit and Risk Committee has adopted a written Statement of Policy with respect to Related Person

1324.text: Transactions (Statement of Policy), governing any transaction, arrangement, or relationship between the

1325.text: Company and any related person where the related person had, has, or will have a direct or indirect material

1326.text: interest. Under the Statement of Policy, the Audit and Risk Committee reviews related person transactions and

1327.text: may approve or ratify them only if it is determined that they are in, or not inconsistent with, the best interests of

1328.text: the Company and its stockholders. When reviewing a related person transaction, the Audit and Risk Committee

1329.text: may take into consideration all of the relevant facts and circumstances available to it, including: (i) the material

1330.text: terms and conditions of the transaction or transactions; (ii) the related person’s relationship to Visa; (iii) the related

1331.text: person’s interest in the transaction, including their position or relationship with, or ownership of, any entity that is a

1332.text: party to or has an interest in the transaction; (iv) the approximate dollar value of the transaction; (v) the availability

1333.text: from other sources of comparable products or services; and (vi) an assessment of whether the transaction is on

1334.text: terms that are comparable to the terms available to us from an unrelated third party.

1335.text: In the event we become aware of a related person transaction that was not previously approved or ratified under

1336.text: the Statement of Policy, the Audit and Risk Committee will evaluate all options available, including ratification,

1337.text: revision, or termination of the related person transaction. The Statement of Policy is intended to augment and

1338.text: work in conjunction with our other policies that include code of conduct or conflict of interest provisions, including

1339.text: our Code of Business Conduct and Ethics.

1340.text: We engage in transactions, arrangements, and relationships with many other entities, including financial

1341.text: institutions and professional organizations, in the ordinary course of our business. Some of our directors,

1342.text: executive officers, greater than five percent stockholders, and their immediate family members, each a related

1343.text: person under the Statement of Policy, may be directors, officers, partners, employees, or stockholders of these

1344.text: entities. We carry out transactions with these entities on customary terms, and, in many instances, our directors

1345.text: and executive officers may not be aware of them. To our knowledge, since the beginning of fiscal year 2022, no

1346.text: related person has had a material interest in any of our business transactions or relationships.

1680.text: peer group and the mix between cash and equity in the director compensation program.

2717.text: We tie a substantial portion of our NEOs’ overall target annual compensation to the achievement of pre-established

2718.text: financial and non-financial performance goals, which include ESG metrics. The Compensation Committee’s

2719.text: objectives are to balance short- and long-term performance criteria, as well as to recognize corporate, business, and

2720.text: individual achievements that impact all stakeholders. The primary principles that guide the compensation program

2721.text: design and administration are summarized below.

2725.text: The key principle of our compensation philosophy is pay for performance. We favor variable

2726.text: “at risk” pay opportunities over fixed pay, with our NEOs’ total compensation determined

2727.text: based on performance measured against annual and long-term goals and stockholder return.

2732.text: We reward performance that meets or exceeds goals that the Compensation Committee

2733.text: establishes with the objective of increasing stockholder value over time, aligning with other

2734.text: stakeholders’ interests, and driving long-term strategic outcomes, including the Company’s

3245.text: Selected Corporate Performance Goals and Results for Fiscal Year 2022

3246.text: The Compensation Committee approved an annual incentive scorecard for fiscal year 2022, similar to the

3247.text: approach it adopted last year. The scorecard balances annual incentive determinations across financial and

3248.text: non-financial strategic priorities, with rigorous, pre-established quantitative and qualitative corporate performance

3249.text: goals in four categories. The Compensation Committee established the goals early in the fiscal year, reviewed

3250.text: progress against each goal quarterly, and evaluated achievement of the goals at year-end. The Compensation

3251.text: Committee determined a payout percentage based on its evaluation of results against the scorecard and then

3252.text: reviewed each NEO’s individual performance against their annual goals to determine whether any further

3253.text: adjustments should be made based on individual performance.

3254.text: These scorecard performance goals were established by reference to our corporate strategy, which is designed to

3255.text: position the Company competitively and thereby deliver superior performance, and which should in turn create

3256.text: value for our stockholders and benefit our employees, clients, and the communities in which we operate. The

3257.text: Compensation Committee expects our NEOs to be focused on a wide range of performance goals that are critical

3258.text: to our corporate strategy, by promoting financial goals along with other priorities that are vital to the Company’s

3259.text: long-term success, such as ESG initiatives. This approach is aligned with our corporate strategy, enhances

3260.text: stockholder value, and reduces the likelihood of excessive risk taking with respect to any particular financial

3261.text: performance goal. Accordingly, the scorecard design takes a holistic approach to the goal-setting process and

3262.text: does not apply specific weighting to the corporate performance goals described below, and the Compensation

3263.text: Committee carefully considered each goal in its overall evaluation of corporate performance. The same scorecard

3264.text: is also used for determining the annual bonus funding for our broad-based employee bonus plan.

3265.text: Each of the performance goals for the annual incentive plan scorecard was established on November 2, 2021,

3266.text: except that preliminary Transactions Growth and Cross-Border Growth goals were finalized on January 24, 2022.

3267.text: The performance goals were established based on the best available information at the time, amidst lingering

3268.text: uncertainty regarding the ongoing effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, including the reopening of borders and

3269.text: resumption of international travel. The goals were designed to be challenging and were expected to incentivize

3270.text: the NEOs to advance Visa’s strategic and operational priorities while the continuing impact of COVID-19 on the

3271.text: Company’s business was uncertain. In addition, these goals were established prior to the war in Ukraine and the

3272.text: unforeseeable impact that this action would have on the Company’s business, as discussed below under

3408.text: Payment of Annual Incentive Plan Awards for Fiscal Year 2022

3409.text: Based on its analysis of Visa’s performance relative to each annual incentive scorecard goal, the Compensation

3410.text: Committee determined that the payout percentage for the 2022 annual incentive plan would be 160% of target

3411.text: and that it would not adjust this payout percentage for any NEO based on its evaluation of the individual

3412.text: achievements described above. In making this assessment, the Compensation Committee considered the impact

3413.text: of the Company’s decision in March 2022 to suspend its operations in Russia due to the war in Ukraine. These

3414.text: unfortunate events were not foreseeable when the Compensation Committee established the performance goals,

3415.text: and they impacted the ability of the Company to achieve some of the goals in the annual incentive scorecard,

3416.text: such as Transactions Growth, for reasons outside of our executives’ control. The Company’s number one priority

3417.text: in the weeks and months following the March 2022 announcement was ensuring the safety and security of our

3418.text: colleagues and their families who were directly impacted, while complying with all applicable global sanctions.

3419.text: Despite these challenges, the Company delivered strong financial and non-financial results relative to the

3420.text: scorecard goals, which the Compensation Committee considered when making its annual incentive

3421.text: determinations. The Compensation Committee determined that the payout percentage of 160% appropriately

3422.text: reflected, in the aggregate, the Company’s and each NEO’s performance relative to the pre-established goals,

3695.text: Our benefits program is designed to be competitive and cost-effective. It is our objective to provide core benefits,

3696.text: including medical, retirement, life insurance, paid time off, and leaves of absence, to all employees and to allow

3697.text: for supplementary non-core benefits to accommodate regulatory, cultural, and practical differences in the various

3698.text: geographies in which we have operations.

3699.text: We sponsor a frozen tax-qualified defined benefit pension plan, which we refer to as the retirement plan. We also

3700.text: sponsor a tax-qualified defined contribution 401(k) plan, which we refer to as the 401k plan, to provide market

3701.text: driven retirement benefits to all eligible employees in the United States.

3702.text: We maintained a non-qualified excess retirement benefit plan and a non-qualified excess 401k plan to make up

3703.text: for the limitations imposed on our tax-qualified plans by the Internal Revenue Code. New contributions to these

3704.text: non-qualified plans ceased to be effective February 1, 2014. We also sponsor an unfunded, non-qualified

3705.text: deferred compensation plan, which we refer to as the deferred compensation plan, which allows executive officers

3706.text: and certain other highly compensated employees to defer a portion of their annual incentive awards to help them

3707.text: with tax planning and to provide competitive benefits. For additional information on these plans, see the sections

3708.text: entitled Executive Compensation – Pension Benefits Table for Fiscal Year 2022 and Executive Compensation –

3709.title: Non-qualified Deferred Compensation for Fiscal Year 2022.

3835.text: As part of our insider trading policy, all employees, including our NEOs, and non-employee directors are

3836.text: prohibited from engaging in short sales of our securities, establishing margin accounts related to our securities,

3837.text: pledging our securities as collateral for a loan, buying or selling puts or calls on our securities, or otherwise

3838.text: engaging in hedging transactions (such as zero-cost collars, exchange funds, and forward sale contracts)

3841.text: We have a Clawback Policy pursuant to which NEOs and other executive officers may be required to reimburse

3842.text: or forfeit incentive compensation paid to them if the financial results upon which the awards were based are

3843.text: materially restated due to fraud, intentional misconduct, or gross negligence of the executive officer.

3844.text: The Clawback Policy permits the Board to determine if it will seek to recover applicable compensation, taking into

3845.text: account the following considerations as it deems appropriate:

3846.text: • Whether the amount of any bonus or equity compensation paid or awarded during the covered time

3847.text: period, based on the achievement of specific performance targets, would have been reduced based on

3849.text: • The likelihood of success of recouping the compensation under governing law relative to the effort

3851.text: • Whether the recoupment may prejudice Visa’s interest in any related proceeding or investigation;

3852.text: • Whether the expense required to recoup the compensation is likely to exceed the amount to be

3854.text: • The passage of time since the occurrence of the misconduct;

3855.text: • Any pending legal action related to the misconduct;

3856.text: • The tax consequences to the affected individual; and

3857.text: • Any other factors the Board may deem appropriate under the circumstances.

3858.text: Under the Clawback Policy, we can require reimbursement or forfeiture of all or a portion of any bonus, incentive

3859.text: payment, equity-based award (including performance shares, restricted stock or restricted stock units, and

3860.text: outstanding stock options) or other compensation to the fullest extent permitted by law. Reimbursement or

3861.text: forfeiture may include compensation paid or awarded during the period covered by the restatement and applies to

3862.text: compensation awarded in periods occurring after the adoption of the Clawback Policy.

3864.text: We believe our Clawback Policy is sufficiently broad to reduce the potential risk that an executive officer would

3865.text: intentionally misstate results to benefit under an incentive program and provides a right of recovery if an executive

3866.text: officer took actions that, in hindsight, should not have been rewarded. In addition, appropriate language regarding

3867.text: the policy has been included in applicable documents and award agreements and our executive officers are

3868.text: required to acknowledge in writing that compensation we have awarded to them may be subject to

3869.text: reimbursement, clawback, or forfeiture pursuant to the terms of the policy and/or applicable law. Further, the

3870.text: equity forfeiture provisions in applicable award agreements would also apply in the event of specified detrimental

3871.text: activity in the absence of a restatement.

4480.text: The following table shows the present value of accumulated benefits payable to our NEOs and the number of

4481.text: years of service credited to each executive under the Visa Retirement Plan and the Visa Excess Retirement

4482.text: Benefit Plan. The value of the benefits is determined using interest rate and mortality rate assumptions consistent

4483.text: with those used in the Company’s fiscal year 2022 audited consolidated financial statements.

4505.text: Kelly Mahon Tullier Visa Retirement Plan 1.5 47,201 –

4507.text: Employer credits under the Visa Retirement Plan were discontinued effective December 31, 2015. Benefit

4508.text: accruals under the Visa Excess Retirement Benefit Plan were discontinued effective February 1, 2014. Each of

4509.text: the executives except Mr. Kelly is fully vested under the Visa Retirement Plan. Mr. Kelly is not an eligible

4510.text: participant in the Visa Retirement Plan or the Visa Excess Retirement Benefit Plan.

4513.text: Under the Visa Retirement Plan, certain U.S.-based employees, including our NEOs, other than Mr. Kelly,

4514.text: generally earn the right to receive certain benefits:

4515.text: • upon retirement at the normal retirement age of 65;

4516.text: • upon early retirement at or after age 55 (or at or after age 50 if hired prior to October 1, 2002) and having

4517.text: completed at least ten years of service with us; or

4518.text: • upon an earlier termination of employment, but solely if the employee is vested at that time.

4519.text: Prior to January 1, 2011, retirement benefits were calculated as the product of 1.25% times the employee’s years

4520.text: of service multiplied by the employee’s monthly final average earnings for the last 60 consecutive months before

4521.text: retirement (or, for employees hired prior to October 1, 2002, the product of 46.25% times the employee’s years of

4522.text: service divided by 25 years, multiplied by the employee’s monthly final average earnings for the 36 highest

4523.text: consecutive months in the last 60 months before retirement). Eligible earnings include salary, overtime, shift

4524.text: differentials, special and merit awards, and short-term cash incentive awards.

4525.text: If an employee retires early, that is, between the ages of 55 and 64 (or between the ages of 50 and 61 if hired

4526.text: prior to October 1, 2002), and has completed at least ten years of service with the Company, the amount of that

4527.text: employee’s benefits is reduced for each complete year that the employee begins receiving early retirement

4528.text: benefits before the age of 65 (or before the age of 62 if hired prior to October 1, 2002). If an employee retires prior

4529.text: to becoming eligible for early or normal retirement, the amount of his or her benefits is actuarially reduced and is

4530.text: generally not as large as if the employee had continued employment until his or her early or normal retirement

4532.text: The Visa Retirement Plan began transitioning to cash balance benefits effective January 1, 2008 and completed

4533.text: the transition effective January 1, 2011. The change to a cash balance benefit formula took effect immediately for

4534.text: employees hired or rehired after December 31, 2007. However, for employees hired before January 1, 2008 (and

4535.text: not rehired thereafter), the applicable Visa Retirement Plan benefit formula described above was grandfathered

4536.text: for a three-year period, and grandfathered employees continued to accrue benefits under that benefit formula.

4537.text: Their accrued benefits at December 31, 2010 (the last day of the grandfathered period) or the date they

4538.text: terminated employment, if earlier, were preserved. Because we completed the conversion to a cash balance plan

4539.text: formula beginning on January 1, 2011, all benefit accruals from that date until December 31, 2015 were under the

4541.text: Prior to January 1, 2016, under the cash balance plan formula, 6% of an employee’s eligible monthly pay was

4542.text: credited each month to the employee’s notional cash balance account, along with interest each month on the

4543.text: account balance at an annualized rate equal to the 30-year U.S. Treasury Bond average annual interest rate for

4544.text: November of the previous calendar year. The employer-provided credits described above ceased after

4545.text: December 31, 2015 and the Visa Retirement Plan had no new participants after that date. Interest credits

4546.text: continue to be provided on balances existing at the time of this freeze. Accrued benefits under the Visa

4547.text: Retirement Plan become fully vested and nonforfeitable after three years of service.

4549.text: Prior to February 1, 2014, we also provided for benefit accruals under an excess retirement benefit plan. To the

4550.text: extent that an employee’s annual retirement income benefit under the Visa Retirement Plan exceeds the

4551.text: limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code, such excess benefit is paid from our non-qualified, unfunded,

4552.text: noncontributory Visa Excess Retirement Benefit Plan. The vesting provisions of, and formula used to calculate the

4553.text: benefit payable pursuant to, the Visa Excess Retirement Benefit Plan are generally the same as those of the Visa

4555.text: Retirement Plan described above, except that benefits are calculated without regard to the Internal Revenue

4556.text: Code tax-qualified plan limits and then offset for benefits paid under the qualified plan. Effective February 1, 2014,

4557.text: we discontinued benefit accruals under the Visa Excess Retirement Benefit Plan.

4558.title: Non-qualified Deferred Compensation for Fiscal Year 2022

4560.text: Under the terms of the Visa Deferred Compensation Plan, eligible participants are able to defer up to 100% of

4561.text: their cash incentive awards if they submit a qualified deferral election. Benefits under the Visa Deferred

4562.text: Compensation Plan will be paid based on one of the following three distribution dates or events previously elected

4563.text: by the participant: (i) immediately upon, or up to five years following, retirement; (ii) immediately upon, or in the

4564.text: January following, termination; or (iii) if specifically elected by the participant, in January in a specified year while

4565.text: actively employed. However, upon a showing of financial hardship and receipt of approval from the plan

4566.text: administrator, a plan participant may be allowed to access funds in his or her deferred compensation account

4567.text: earlier than his or her existing distribution election(s). Benefits can be received either as a lump sum payment or

4568.text: in annual installments, except in the case of pre-retirement termination, in which case the participant must receive

4569.text: the benefit in a lump sum. Participants are always fully vested in their deferrals under the Visa Deferred

4570.text: Compensation Plan. Upon termination of the Visa Deferred Compensation Plan within 12 months of a “change of

4571.text: control,” participants’ benefits under the Visa Deferred Compensation Plan will be paid immediately in a lump

4574.text: Under the terms of the Visa Directors Deferred Compensation Plan, non-employee directors are able to defer up

4575.text: to 100% of their fees payable in cash if they submit a qualified deferral election. Unless a participant’s separation

4576.text: from service constitutes his or her “retirement,” the participant’s benefits under the Visa Directors Deferred

4577.text: Compensation Plan will be paid in a lump sum in cash, as previously elected by the participant, either (i) within 90

4578.text: days following the date of the separation from service, or (ii) on the next January 1 following the separation from

4579.text: service. Participants are always fully vested in their deferrals under the Visa Directors Deferred Compensation

4580.text: Plan. Upon termination of the Visa Director Deferred Compensation Plan within 12 months of a “change of

4581.text: control,” participants’ benefits under the Visa Director Deferred Compensation Plan will be paid immediately in a

4582.text: lump sum. Further, under the terms of the restricted stock unit award agreements applicable to directors, provided

4583.text: they submit a qualified deferral election, directors are eligible to defer settlement of the restricted stock units they

4584.text: receive for service on the Board until the later of (i) the first anniversary of the grant date or (ii) a date or dates

4585.text: during their service or following their separation from service, subject to earlier settlement upon the participant’s

4586.text: death or following a change in control.

4587.title: Visa 401k Plan and Visa Excess 401k Plan

4588.text: The Visa 401k Plan is a tax-qualified 401(k) retirement savings plan pursuant to which all of our U.S.-based

4589.text: employees, including our NEOs, are able to contribute up to 50%, or 13% for highly compensated employees, of

4590.text: their salary up to the limit prescribed by the Internal Revenue Code to the Visa 401k Plan on a pre-tax basis.

4591.text: Employees also have the option of contributing on an after-tax basis up to 50%, or 13% for highly compensated

4592.text: employees, of salary or a combination of pre-tax and after-tax contributions that do not exceed 50%, or 13% for

4593.text: highly compensated employees, of salary. All contributions are subject to the Internal Revenue Code limits. If an

4594.text: employee reaches the statutory pre-tax contribution limit during the calendar year, an employee may continue to

4595.text: make contributions to the Visa 401k Plan on an after-tax basis, subject to any applicable statutory limits.

4596.text: During fiscal year 2022, we contributed a matching amount equal to 200% of the first 3% of salary that was

4597.text: contributed by senior executives, including NEOs, to the Visa 401k Plan. All other employees were eligible for a

4598.text: matching amount equal to 200% of the first 5% of salary contributed to the Visa 401k Plan. Starting January 1,

4599.text: 2023, the matching amount for senior executives, including NEOs, will be equal to 200% of the first 5% of salary

4601.text: contributed. This change reduces administration, promotes consistency between plan participants, and provides

4602.text: our executive leadership with the same matching percentage that was already provided to other participants. All

4603.text: employee and matching contributions to the Visa 401k Plan are fully vested upon contribution.

4604.text: Prior to February 1, 2014, we also provided for a contribution in an excess 401k plan. Because the Internal

4605.text: Revenue Code limits the maximum amount a company and an employee can contribute to an employee’s 401(k)

4606.text: plan account each year, we continued to provide the matching contribution, after the applicable Internal Revenue

4607.text: Code limits are reached, to the Visa Excess 401k Plan, which is a non-qualified noncontributory retirement

4608.text: savings plan. Employees are eligible to participate in the Visa Excess 401k Plan if their salaries are greater than

4609.text: the Internal Revenue Code pay cap or if the total of their contributions and our matching contributions to the Visa

4610.text: 401k Plan exceed the Internal Revenue Code benefit limit. The features of the Visa Excess 401k Plan are

4611.text: generally the same as under the Visa 401k Plan, except that benefits cannot be rolled over to an IRA or another

4612.text: employer’s qualified plan. Effective February 1, 2014, we discontinued any future contributions to the Visa Excess

4712.title: Potential Payments upon Termination or Change of Control

4714.text: We believe that it is appropriate to provide severance pay to an executive officer whose employment is

4715.text: involuntarily terminated by us without “cause” or whose employment is voluntarily terminated by the executive for

4716.text: “good reason” within two years following a change of control (each as defined in the Visa Inc. Executive

4717.text: Severance Plan). These severance benefits are intended to secure the continued services of executive officers,

4718.text: provide them with certain benefits in the event of a covered termination, and encourage their continued dedication

4719.text: to their duties notwithstanding the possibility or occurrence of a change in control. We believe the level of

4720.text: severance provided by our Executive Severance Plan is reasonable, responsible in value, consistent with the

4721.text: practices of our compensation peer group, and necessary to attract and retain key high-performing employees.

4722.text: Our NEOs are participants in the Executive Severance Plan, which provides for a capped, lump sum severance

4723.text: upon a qualifying termination of two times the sum of the executive’s base salary and target annual incentive

4724.text: award, and a prorated bonus for any partial performance period under the annual incentive plan, along with

4725.text: continued health benefits for two years post-termination. These benefits are subject to the NEO’s timely execution

4726.text: and non-revocation of a waiver and release of claims. For purposes of the plan, a qualifying termination is limited

4727.text: to an involuntary termination by us without cause at any time or a resignation by the participant for good reason

4728.text: within two years following a change of control. Executive Severance Plan participants are required to comply with

4729.text: certain restrictive covenants, including obligations to uphold confidentiality and to abstain from soliciting Visa’s

4730.text: employees, customers, and clients for eighteen months following a qualifying termination of the participant’s

4731.text: employment. Participants are also generally bound by the confidentiality, intellectual property, and non-solicitation

4732.text: provisions of any Confidential Information and Property Agreement, Proprietary Information Agreement, and/or

4733.text: any similar agreement previously executed by the applicable participant and the confidentiality provisions under

4734.text: Visa’s Code of Business Conduct and Ethics. The Executive Severance Plan does not provide for any gross-ups

4735.text: for excise taxes imposed as a result of severance or other payments deemed made in connection with a change

4738.text: Pursuant to the terms of certain award agreements under the 2007 Equity Incentive Compensation Plan, if the

4739.text: employment of an NEO is involuntarily terminated by Visa without “cause” or voluntarily terminated by the NEO

4740.text: for “good reason” within two years following a change of control (as such terms are defined in the 2007 Equity

4741.text: Incentive Compensation Plan or applicable award agreement), then the unvested portion of any such equity

4742.text: incentive award will become fully vested (and at target levels, with respect to performance shares). There are no

4743.text: “single-trigger” payments available to NEOs upon a change of control. Under the terms of the equity incentive

4744.text: awards granted since November 19, 2021, if an NEO is involuntarily terminated by Visa without cause, the

4745.text: awards are paid on a pro-rated basis measured from the date of grant to the date of termination. Similar to the

4746.text: cash benefits described under Executive Compensation – Potential Payments upon Termination or Change of

4747.predicted header: above, these equity award terms are reasonable, consistent with the

4748.text: practices of our compensation peer group, and necessary to attract and retain key high-performing employees.

4958.text: Given the worldwide geographical distribution of our employee population, we use a variety of pay elements to

4959.text: structure the compensation arrangements of our employees. A significant number of our employees around the

4960.text: world participate in our annual cash bonus and equity incentive award plans. Consequently, to identify the median

4961.text: employee, we selected base salary or wages plus overtime pay, annual cash bonus plan payments, and equity

4962.text: award grant values as the most appropriate measure of compensation. We measured compensation for our

4964.text: measurement date, which was the last day of our 2021 fiscal year, because it provided the most accurate

4967.text: compensation arrangements that we believe would significantly impact our pay ratio disclosure, a significant

4968.text: change in the circumstances of the median employee identified in 2021 occurred. As a result, for 2022, we

5026.text: We are asking our Class A common stockholders to approve, on an advisory basis, the compensation of our

5027.text: NEOs as described in this proxy statement, including the section entitled Compensation Discussion and Analysis,

5029.text: proposal, gives our Class A common stockholders the opportunity to express their views on our NEOs’

5031.text: As described in detail under Compensation Discussion and Analysis above, our executive compensation

5032.text: programs are designed to attract, motivate, and retain our NEOs, who are critical to our success. Under these

5033.text: programs, our NEOs are rewarded for the achievement of specific annual, long-term, and strategic performance

5034.text: goals and the realization of increased value to stakeholders. Please read the Compensation Discussion and

5035.predicted header: section of this proxy statement for additional details about our executive compensation programs,

5036.text: including information about the fiscal year 2022 compensation of our NEOs.

5037.text: The Say-on-Pay vote is advisory, and therefore not binding on the Company, the Compensation Committee, or

5038.text: our Board. However, our Board and the Compensation Committee value the views of our stockholders and will

5039.text: carefully review and consider the voting results for this proposal when evaluating our executive compensation

5040.text: programs. We currently conduct annual advisory votes to approve the compensation of our NEOs, and we expect

5041.text: to conduct the next advisory Say-on-Pay vote at our 2023 annual meeting of stockholders.

5046.title: FUTURE ADVISORY VOTES TO APPROVE EXECUTIVE

5048.text: The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act and Section 14A of the Exchange Act provide

5049.text: stockholders the opportunity to indicate how frequently the Company should hold future advisory votes to approve

5050.text: the compensation of our NEOs. Stockholders may indicate whether they would prefer to have future advisory

5051.text: votes to approve executive compensation every year, every two years, every three years, or abstain from voting

5053.text: After careful consideration, the Board recommends that future advisory votes to approve compensation of our

5054.text: NEOs be held annually. Our Board believes that holding a vote every year is the most appropriate option because

5055.text: (i) it would enable our stockholders to provide us with input regarding the compensation of our NEOs on a timely

5056.text: basis; and (ii) it is consistent with our practice of engaging with our stockholders, and obtaining their input, on our

5057.text: corporate governance matters and our executive compensation philosophy, policies, and practices.

5058.text: Stockholders are not voting to approve or disapprove the Board’s recommendation. Instead, stockholders may

5059.text: indicate their preference regarding the frequency of future advisory votes to approve the compensation of our

5060.text: NEOs by selecting one year, two years, or three years. For the reasons discussed above, we are asking our

5061.text: stockholders to vote for an advisory vote to approve the compensation for our NEOs every one year.

5062.text: The frequency with which future advisory votes to approve the compensation of our NEOs are held is advisory,

5063.text: and therefore not binding. Although the vote is non-binding, the Compensation Committee and the Board value

5064.text: your opinion and will consider the outcome of the vote in establishing the frequency with which the advisory vote

5065.text: to approve the compensation of our NEOs will be held in the future.

5072.text: The Audit and Risk Committee is responsible for the appointment, compensation, retention, and oversight of the

5073.text: independent public accounting firm retained to audit the Company’s financial statements. The Audit and Risk

5074.text: Committee has appointed KPMG LLP as our independent registered public accounting firm to audit the financial

5075.text: statements of Visa Inc. and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2023. KPMG has been our

5076.text: independent auditor since our initial public offering in 2008, and KPMG audited our financial statements for fiscal

5077.text: year 2022. The Audit and Risk Committee also periodically considers whether there should be a rotation of

5078.text: independent registered public accounting firms because the Audit and Risk Committee believes it is important for

5079.text: the registered public accounting firm to maintain independence and objectivity. In determining whether to

5080.text: reappoint KPMG, the Audit and Risk Committee considered several factors, including:

5081.text: • the length of time KPMG has been engaged;

5083.text: • KPMG’s capability and expertise in handling the complexity of Visa’s global operations in our industry;

5084.text: • historical and recent performance, including the extent and quality of KPMG’s communications with the

5085.text: Audit and Risk Committee, and feedback from management regarding KPMG’s overall performance;

5086.text: • recent PCAOB inspection reports on the firm; and

5087.text: • the appropriateness of KPMG’s fees, both on an absolute basis and as compared with its peers.

5088.text: The Audit and Risk Committee believes that the continued retention of KPMG as our independent registered

5089.text: public accounting firm is in the best interest of the Company and our stockholders, and we are asking our

5090.text: stockholders to ratify the selection of KPMG as our independent registered public accounting firm for fiscal year

5091.text: 2023. Although ratification is not required, the Board is submitting a proposal to ratify KPMG’s appointment to our

5092.text: stockholders because we value our stockholders’ views and as a matter of good corporate practice. In the event

5093.text: that our stockholders fail to ratify KPMG as the Company’s independent registered public accounting firm, it will

5094.text: be considered a recommendation to the Audit and Risk Committee to consider the selection of a different firm.

5095.text: Even if the appointment is ratified, the Audit and Risk Committee may in its discretion select a different

5096.text: independent registered public accounting firm at any time during the fiscal year if it determines that such a change

5097.text: would be in the best interests of the Company and our stockholders.

5098.text: A representative of KPMG will be present at the Annual Meeting and will have the opportunity to make a

5099.text: statement if he or she desires to do so and will be available to respond to appropriate questions.

5149.title: Request for Board of Directors to Adopt Policy for an Independent Chair

5151.text: Shareholders request the Board of Directors adopt as policy, and amend the bylaws as necessary, to require

5152.text: hereafter that the Chair of the Board of Directors be an independent member of the Board, consistent with

5153.text: applicable law and existing contracts. If the Board determines that a Chair who was independent when selected is

5154.text: no longer independent, the Board shall select a new Chair who satisfies the requirements of the policy within a

5157.text: The Chief Executive Officer of Visa Inc. is also Board Chairman. We believe these roles – each with separate,

5158.text: different responsibilities that are critical to the health of a successful corporation – are greatly diminished when

5159.text: held by a singular company official, thus weakening its governance structure.

5161.text: • According to the Council of Institutional Investors (https://bit.ly/3pKrtJK), “A CEO who also serves as

5162.text: chair can exert excessive influence on the board and its agenda, weakening the board’s oversight of

5163.text: management. Separating the chair and CEO positions reduces this conflict, and an independent chair

5164.text: provides the clearest separation of power between the CEO and the rest of the board.”

5165.text: • A 2014 report from Deloitte (https://bit.ly/3vQGqe1) concluded, “The chairman should lead the board and

5166.text: there should be a clear division of responsibilities between the chairman and the chief executive officer

5168.text: • A pair of business law professors wrote for Harvard Business Review (https://bit.ly/3xvcIOA) in March

5169.text: 2020 that “letting the CEO chair the board can compromise board discussion quality, weakening the

5170.text: corporation’s risk management ability... Splitting the CEO and board chair jobs between two people can

5171.text: help strengthen the quality of questions the corporation asks itself. When those questions remain weak,

5172.text: the organization is less likely to develop strategies that mitigate risk.”

5173.text: • Proxy adviser Glass Lewis advised (https://bit.ly/3xwuJwa) in 2021, “the presence of an independent

5174.text: chair fosters the creation of a thoughtful and dynamic board not dominated by the views of senior

5175.text: management. Further, we believe that the separation of these two key roles eliminates the conflict of

5176.text: interest that inevitably occurs when a CEO is responsible for self-oversight.”

5178.title: Statement of the Board of Directors in Opposition to Proposal 5

5179.text: The Board of Directors recommends that stockholders vote AGAINST this proposal, for the following reasons:

5180.text: • We believe flexibility in Board leadership structure is more suitable for the Company than the rigid and

5181.text: prescriptive approach set forth in the Stockholder Proposal.

5182.text: • We believe Visa’s current Board leadership structure, which includes a strong Lead Independent

5183.text: Director, best serves the Company and our stockholders.

5184.text: • Visa’s strong corporate governance practices provide effective, independent Board oversight.

5188.text: light of the needs of the Board and the Company at any given time. Accordingly, as discussed under Corporate

5189.predicted header: , Visa’s governing documents provide the Board with the flexibility to

5190.text: determine the optimal leadership structure for the Company, including, when appropriate, separating the positions

5191.text: of Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer as will occur when Ryan Mclnerney succeeds Al Kelly as

5192.text: Visa’s next Chief Executive Officer, effective February 1, 2023. We believe that the Company and our

5193.text: stockholders benefit from this flexibility, and that the Board is best positioned to make this determination given our

5194.text: directors’ knowledge of the Company’s leadership team, strategic goals, opportunities, and challenges. We

5195.text: believe that it is in the best interests of Visa and our stockholders for the Board to continue to determine the most

5196.text: effective leadership structure for Visa on a case-by-case basis, rather than take a rigid approach to Board

5232.text: In addition to our Lead Independent Director, independent directors chair the Board’s four standing committees,

5235.text: Our Board recognizes that circumstances may change such that a different structure may be warranted to support

5236.text: the Company’s needs. As a result, the Board periodically reviews the Board’s leadership structure and its

5237.text: appropriateness, given the needs of the Board and the Company at such time. In connection with Chief Executive

5266.text: mix of skills, experience, tenure, and diversity that promotes and supports the Company’s long-term strategy;

5268.text: • Proactive and Ongoing Stockholder Engagement Program – We have proactive, ongoing

5269.text: engagement with our stockholders throughout the year focused on corporate governance, corporate

5273.text: investors this year and our Board is provided with stockholders’ feedback;

5274.text: • Robust Board, Committee, and Director Evaluation Process – Our Board and each of its committees

5275.text: conduct an annual evaluation facilitated by an independent third party, which includes a qualitative

5276.text: assessment by each director of the performance of the Board and the committee or committees on which

5278.text: • Independent Standing Board Committees – The Board’s Audit and Risk Committee, Nominating and

5279.text: Corporate Governance Committee, Compensation Committee, and Finance Committee are each

5280.text: composed entirely of independent directors. This entrusts the oversight of critical matters to independent

5281.text: directors, such as the annual evaluation of the Chief Executive Officer’s performance, the evaluation of

5282.text: the Board and its Committees, and the compensation of Visa’s executive officers; and

5283.text: • Executive Sessions of the Independent Directors – The non-employee, independent members of our

5284.text: Board and all committees of the Board generally meet in executive session without management present

5285.text: during their Board and Committee meetings. Our Lead Independent Director presides over executive

5286.text: sessions of the Board, and the committee chairs, each of whom is independent, preside over executive

5288.text: As a result of the above information, the Board believes that the rigid approach to Visa’s Board’s leadership

5289.text: structure requested by this stockholder proposal is not necessary and not in the best interest of our stockholders.

5370.text: The determination of whether a proposal is “routine” or “non-routine” will be made by the NYSE or by Broadridge

5371.text: Financial Solutions, our independent agent to receive and tabulate stockholder votes, based on NYSE rules that

5372.text: regulate member brokerage firms. If a proposal is deemed “routine” and you do not give instructions to your

5373.text: broker or nominee, they may, but are not required to, vote your shares with respect to the proposal. If the

5374.text: proposal is deemed “non-routine” and you do not give instructions to your broker or nominee, they may not vote

5375.text: your shares with respect to the proposal and the shares will be treated as broker non-votes.

5376.text: Therefore, if you do not provide voting instructions to your broker or nominee, your broker or nominee may only

5438.text: she does not have more votes cast FOR than AGAINST his or her re-election, the Nominating and Corporate Governance

5441.text: Company and its stockholders. The Board will decide whether to accept or reject the contingent resignation at its next

5442.text: regularly scheduled meeting, but in no event later than 120 days following certification of the election results. The Board

5443.text: will publicly disclose its decision and rationale.

5508.title: Stockholder Nomination of Director Candidates and Other Stockholder

5510.text: The submission deadline for stockholder proposals to be included in our proxy materials for the 2024 annual

5511.text: meeting of stockholders pursuant to Rule 14a-8 of the Exchange Act is August 3, 2023. All such proposals must

5512.text: be in writing and received by our Corporate Secretary electronically at corporatesecretary@visa.com or by mail at

5513.text: Visa Inc., P.O. Box 193243, San Francisco, CA 94119 by the close of business on the required deadline in order

5514.text: to be considered for inclusion in our proxy materials for the 2024 annual meeting of stockholders. Submission of a

5515.text: proposal before the deadline does not guarantee its inclusion in our proxy materials.

5516.text: Under our Bylaws, director nominations and other business may be brought before an annual meeting of

5517.text: stockholders only by or at the direction of the Board or by a stockholder entitled to vote who has submitted a

5518.text: proposal in accordance with the requirements of our Bylaws. To nominate a candidate or submit a proposal for

5519.text: consideration at our 2024 annual meeting pursuant to our advance notice bylaw provisions, stockholders must

5520.text: deliver or mail their nomination submission or other stockholder notice of a proposal so that it is received by our

5521.text: Corporate Secretary no earlier than 120 days and no later than 90 days prior to the date of the annual meeting.

5522.text: However, if we provide stockholders less than 100 days’ notice or other prior public disclosure of the date of our

5523.text: 2024 annual meeting, we must receive any stockholder nomination or proposal no later than the close of business

5524.text: on the 10th day following the earlier of the day on which we mailed or otherwise publicly disclosed notice of the

5525.text: meeting date. In addition to satisfying the deadlines in the advance notice provisions of our Bylaws, a stockholder

5526.text: who intends to solicit proxies in support of nominees submitted under these advance notice provisions must

5527.text: provide the notice required under Rule 14a-19 to the Corporate Secretary no later than November 25, 2023.

5528.text: In addition, the Company’s Bylaws permit up to 20 stockholders owning 3% or more of our Class A common stock

5529.text: for a period of at least three years to nominate up to 20% of the Board and include these nominees in our proxy

5530.text: materials, subject to certain provisions included in our Bylaws. To nominate a candidate to be considered at our

5531.text: 2024 annual meeting pursuant to our proxy access bylaw provisions, stockholders must deliver or mail their

5532.text: nomination so that it is received by our Corporate Secretary no earlier than the close of business on July 4, 2023

5533.text: and no later than the close of business on August 3, 2023. However, if the 2024 annual meeting is more than 30

5534.text: days before or after the anniversary of the date of the 2023 annual meeting, or if no annual meeting was held in

5535.text: the preceding year, stockholders must deliver or mail their nomination so that it is received by our Corporate

5536.text: Secretary no earlier than the close of business on the 150th day prior to the 2024 annual meeting date, and no

5537.text: later than the close of business on the later of the 120th day prior to the 2024 annual meeting date or the 10th day

5538.text: following the day we publicly disclose the 2024 annual meeting date.

5539.text: The nomination or notice of a proposal must include all of the information specified in our Bylaws. For a

5540.text: nomination, the required information includes identifying and stockholding information about the nominee,

5541.text: information about the stockholder making the nomination, and the stockholder’s ownership of and agreements

5542.text: related to our stock. It also must include the nominee’s consent to serve if elected. Please refer to the relevant

5543.text: provisions of our Bylaws for additional information and requirements regarding stockholder nominations or other

5544.text: stockholder proposals. A copy of our Bylaws may be obtained by visiting the Investor Relations page of our

5545.text: website at investor.visa.com under “Corporate Governance” or by contacting our Corporate Secretary.

5547.text: The SEC has adopted rules that allow a company to deliver a single proxy statement or annual report to an

5548.text: address shared by two or more of its stockholders. This method of delivery, known as “householding,” permits us

5549.text: to realize significant cost savings, reduces the amount of duplicate information stockholders receive, and reduces

5550.text: the environmental impact of printing and mailing documents to our stockholders. Under this process, certain

5552.text: stockholders will receive only one copy of our proxy materials and any additional proxy materials that are

5553.text: delivered until such time as one or more of these stockholders notifies us that they want to receive separate

5554.text: copies. Any stockholders who object to or wish to begin householding may contact our Investor Relations

5555.text: Department at (650) 432-7644, InvestorRelations@visa.com or Investor Relations, Visa Inc., P.O. Box 8999, San

5556.text: Francisco, CA 94128-8999. We will send an individual copy of the proxy statement to any stockholder who

5557.text: revokes their consent to householding within 30 days of our receipt of such revocation.
